Subject: Re: [neat] HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=32323338; y=blfsnl-nOKAKpVPQ6en4X4Ags3oJGO-yrLrn8Fim0JJ9QRbsZw

Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> Hi everyone, as some of you know, we have been working for a while
> now on turning the patterns output by CPPNs into neural networks.

Hi,

I have a few naive questions.  First of all, this is a novel idea, 
thanks for publishing it.

My first thought as reading through the paper: Does this simply boil 
down to an extra (albeit useful) level of indirection?  Of course, the 
next question: Is this indirection helpful?

The things not addressed, that I'm wondering..

* So, this is probably most useful for generating meganode networks. 
The kind of stuff you might put on an FPGA.  Or, is it beating straight 
NEAT even on smaller problems?

* But, let's say in that case (meganode networks)..  with the complexity 
of the substrate configuration, comes required complexity and detail in 
the CPNN.  So, I'm wondering, on non "toy" problems, how complex do 
CPNNs need to become, and does NEAT get them there?

* And, again in the meganode case.. what if you cannot a priori 
determine a suitable substrate configuration?  The more "unnatural" (I'm 
missing the right word for this) the configuration, the more depth and 
complexity needed in the CPNN.

* So, we're left with manual substrate configuration.. and perhaps 
that's answered in the yet-to-be-published part of your research?  I 
suppose you might be able to come up with some evolvable substrate 
encoding schemes.

* Finally, I'd sure like to hear more on your ideas about hidden nodes 
in the substrate.  In the one paper I read ('D'Ambrosio), it's only 
briefly mentioned in a few spots.

Thanks again for the papers.  I like the concept.  I particularly like 
the feeling when I get when I read it, that this idea probably stemmed 
from that 2d function evolver/plotter thing you used to make the 
spaceship some years ago.

--Steve
